Isn't saying "so if the sun shines tomorrow, give thanks to quantum mechanics" a bit confusing?
I mean even if the phenomena studied in quantum mechanics are all that cause the sun to emit electromagnetic radiation in the visible spectrum, it is not quantum mechanics (a study of those phenomena) itself that causes this but rather those phenomena.
It (saying the aforementioned) also, sort of, implies that the theoretical models that scientists have built in quantum mechanics, to try to make sense of certain natural occurrences, are the reason for these occurrences - as if these models preceded them; but they are just humanity’s attempts to understand what was occuring in nature - these models came later.
So, we can be grateful to the processes due to which the sun shines. We can be grateful that these processes, described/studied by quantum mechanics, exist. And we can be grateful to quantum mechanics - which studies these processes - for enabling us to acquire a better understanding of the emission of light from the sun than we'd have otherwise had.

If anybody is wondering, the Sun is steadily increasing it's power output, or luminosity. Its luminosity has increased by about 20%, while its radius has increased by about 10%, since its formation 4.5bn years ago. In another 5.5bn years its luminosity will gradually increase by another 80%, and its radius will increase by another 40%, before it starts expanding to become a red giant. Throughout these 10bn years its temperature will remain the same, only decreasing as it expands into a red giant. After 12 billion years since its formation its temperature will have dropped to about 4600K, from 5700K.

Here's the math:
E=mc^2 where m = 2 x the mass of an electron
                  so m = 2 x 9.11 x 10^(-31) kg
; E=2 x 9.11 x 10^(-31) x (3 x 10^8)^2
  E=1.64 x 10^(-13) J
  Energy of each of the two photons = (1.64 x 10^(-13))/2
  Energy of each photon = 8.2 x 10^(-14) J
  
  Frequency of gamma rays: 10^18+ Hz
  Energy of photon = Planck's Constant x Frequency
; Frequency = Energy/Planck's Constant
; Frequency = (8.2 x 10^(-14))/(6.63 x 10^(-34))
; Frequency = 1.23 x 10^20 = Gamma photons

The 2 gamma photons then create a cascade of lower and lower energy photons as they are absorbed and re-emitted by electrons orbiting atoms inside the sun, they do this from near the centre of the sun until they reach the surface of the sun where the many photons are emitted for the last time.

The positron is almost immediately converted into energy, because they will only have to travel an atomic scale distance before they come into contact with an electron (and free positrons move at at huge speeds).
When a particle comes into contact with its antiparticle (in this case an electron and positron) they are converted entirely into energy, in the form of 2 gamma photons (electromagnetic waves that transfer extremely high amounts of energy)

There seems to be a lot of confusion about fission vs fusion.  Fusion is binding two atoms together (e.g. H + H = He).  Fission is breaking them apart.  They BOTH release energy as part of the reaction.  Fusion is what happens inside the sun, and fission is what happens in your nuclear bomb.  Fission is also what happens in your nuclear power plant (but not in a chain reaction like the bomb).  Fusion is what we'd like to use in powerplants as there are no radioactive byproducts.

@UltimaxNoobTuber Hydrogen and helium aren't fundamental particles. Hydrogen has a proton and zero or more neutrons, depending on which isotope of hydrogen it is. Helium has two protons and a neutron. Protons and neutrons are in turn made up of quarks which are the fundamental particles. An electron, on the other hand, is a fundamental particle. So a hydrogen atom that has only a proton can fuse with a hydrogen atom that has a proton and a neutron to form helium.
